technical skills.

Ok.
As for my agenda,

first I will quickly talk about
the basic pre-requisites for people

Next we will

discuss some of our Amazon
VPC technical concepts.

If you are interested in the topic

When you see this slide,
do you feel overwhelmed?

If you want to interview for
a networking job,

do you need to understand
every protocol?
Actually not.
Just like what we said earlier,
what we need is… of course if
you know everything, it’s a plus.
But if you have in-depth knowledge
in a certain technical domain or

if you have solved many
issues in this domain,
we also like
this kind of interviewees.
Some might ask whether
Amazon services actually use
so many protocols.
I can actually give some examples.
Take Layer 1 for example,

there is a service called
Direct Connect.
This service is used to interconnect
the clients’ data centers.
There is an actual physical fiber
line linking to the Amazon cloud.

You can think of it like
the clients’ data center is
directly linked to the cloud
and you can visit it directly.
When dealing this kind of issue,
we actually need to know how to

measure and interpret the
fiber optic signal.
For the fiber optic configuration,
do they match on both ends?
If it is not correct, we may
not be able to establish a link.
Let’s take it to the next level,
to VLAN.
After establishing the fiber optic,
you need to verify whether the
VLANs on both ends match.
After verifying VLAN,
we may need to check BGP, because
after the line is established,

you need to use the BGP protocol
to communicate the routing.
And for routing, we also
need to cover routing priority.
So you need to know how to
set up and determine

the routing priority, and
how to decide on the
packets and routing configuration.
Let’s proceed with the cloud.

Many cloud clients use
NAT Gateway, and it is similar
to the conventional channel NAT.

So if a client has
an issue with the NAT today,
due to NAT’s inherent restrictions
related to TCP/IP,
you will need to have knowledge
in TCP/IP when you
want to solve the issue.
Finally on the highest level, when

you want to host
a website,
you may need an ELB
for load balancing.

Load balancing supports
both HTTP and HTTPS, so when
you are solving issues for clients,

you will need to understand the
differences between HTTP and HTTPS,
and their technical details.
The first tip is that
if you are to apply for any
of the profiles under our
Cloud Support Engineers,
I’d suggest that you take a look

at the services provided by AWS
for this profile, and what
protocols are used, so that you can
prepare for these protocols.

If you happen to have
relevant knowledge in them,
it is excellent.
If not, you can prepare yourself.
As our interviews actually
focus on the protocols
that our Amazon services use.
For example,

if you are interviewing
for a profile under DB,

as we provide an RDS service
such as MySQL,

you probably need to understand
how MySQL works, or maybe
how to operate it.
Ok.
Let’s start with VPC.

VPC is
a virtual network.

Simply put, it means that
you can create your own
private network on Amazon.

You can put
Amazon EC2 in it.
EC2 is actually an
instance of a virtual machine.
On the virtual machine,
you can add your own OS.
This virtual network is similar to
the ones established in an actual

physical network or the kind
in a data center.
So we must also ensure that
you can set up an IP Address,
and set up a subnet, and
then you can set up routing rules,
and even firewall rules.
Take one of our client cases
for example.

Our client probably has a
service on the ground that they
want to migrate to the cloud.
As a result, they would

come talk to our
Support Engineers.

And we will provide them with the
best practice for network planning,
or we can provide them with timely
assistance if they have any
issue during the migration.
Ok, then
when you create a VPC,

in addition to the
EC2 we mentioned,

you can also add
various services in it.

These services will be
located in the VPC,
in the isolated subnet.
They can talk to each other.
Nobody else can access them.
Ok.
Next let’s look at
Region.

Region
is like a geographical region.
In AWS Cloud,
you can set your machine, such as
a website service, to be located in
several locations around the world.

Each location is
like a Region.
We name each Region after
where it is located.

For example,
we have a Region called London,

and another Region called
North California.

One is in the US, and
the other is in Europe.
A code is used for each Region.

For example, London is
eu-west-2.
And

North California is
us-west-1.
When a client is deciding
on which Region to choose,
the main considerations are that,

first of all, you need to think
about the access delay.
Secondly, it’s the regulations.

Some European clients may need to
comply with certain regulations,

so they need to put the
data centers in Europe.

Ok, here you can see
the Console.

How do we choose Region on
Amazon’s Console?
It’s very easy.

You can see there is a
drop-down menu on the right.

Here you can see a variety of
Regions on Amazon.
Just with one click,

you can create the resources you
want in that Region, such as
creating an EC2.
You can set up a website there.
Ok, in every Availability Region,

oh sorry,
in every Region, there are also the
Availability Zones, and they are
mainly used for high availability.
It is what we call “HA”.
Because if you
put your service in only
one Availability Zone, and if this
Availability Zone is affected by
an accident, such as tornados,
lightning, flood, earthquakes, or
an irregularity in the data center,

and you don’t have another data
center you can switch to.
So we actually want to let them

know about the Availability Zones.
We suggest that the clients put
their data in 2 Availability Zones.
As for the Availability Zones,

every Region has its own
independent Availability Zones.
They are marked with 1a or 1b
after the Region Code.

How do you divide
networks within a VPC?
In a VPC…

In a VPC,
you can see on the right side,
we give each subnet in a
VPC an IP CIDR.

With this IP CIDR,
you can divide the
network blocks for each subnet.

Later on when you
are making a Route Table
or creating firewall rules,
you can make quick

designations, such as for
10.0.0.0/24, where
you want to route the traffic.
This is our VPC Console.
It’s easy to launch a subnet.
You can see

on the right hand side.
You only need to enter your CIDR,
and on the right side,
it’ll tell you the available IP
addresses for this CIDR.
No need for binary calculations.

Ok, then how to direct the
traffic out?

or how to
communicate with a route table?

Actually we can
create a route table for
each of the VPC subnet.
You can designate an IP CIDR
for this route table to direct it
to one of our networked appliances
You can see from here that it is

the Console for setting up our
route table.
For example,

I can direct my
10.0.0.0/16 to
the Internet Gateway.
What is an Internet Gateway?
The Internet Gateway means that,

if the client wants to
create a VPC, and you want the
VPC to connect to the Internet,
and to access the, for example,
your Web Server via BMI
on the Internet, or

you want to retrieve some
webpages or to download
some new software,

you will need to create a
Internet Gateway.

An Internet Gateway is
hosted by our Amazon.
It can be enabled with one click.
So our client can enable the
Internet Gateway with one click.
It is a horizontally scaled and
highly available VPC component.
As part of its purpose, when you
enable the Internet Gateway,

if your EC2 traffic flows
out of the Internet Gateway,
we will automatically add the
external IP for this EC2 for you.
So people on the Internet
will actually see your

Public IP moving outbound
to access your,
for example, remote server.
They will not see your private IP.

Because other people can’t login
back to your private IP.
If I want to restrict, like
if I want my EC2 to only
have outbound connections, but
I don’t want others to access me.
Why is there a such demand?

It’s because
we know that
if there is an EC2, an instance, or
a virtual machine on the Internet,
then it would have a Public IP.
If you allow people to access it,

first of all, you will be faced
with a lot of web crawlers.
Secondly, many malicious attackers
will try to scan for any open ports

and find out about
your services,

so that they can
infiltrate or attack them.
So if your demand today is
simply that you want to connect

to Internet and download
some webpages, we’d
suggest that you use NAT.
For NAT, Amazon provides

something called
NAT Gateway.
Just as what we said,

it has exactly the same functions
as the conventional NAT.
It is also managed by us.

So with this
NAT creation process and
the network scheme on the right,
I’d like to conclude on what
we’ve just mentioned.
In a VPC, there is a subnet,
and there is NAT. On the left,
it’s the NAT creation screen.
You can see that it’s actually
very simple.
You only need to decide the subnet,
and the IP you want to allocate.
On the right,

you can see it is
actually the planning of

a typical NAT and a subnet
for a web server.
Below
you have a private subnet,
and you have a public subnet.
In the private subnet below,

you usually put something
with a Private IP,
such as Database Servers.

These servers don’t need to
be accessed by external parties,

but they may need to
download some webpages,

so they will use the
Route Table, such as the

Main Route Table on
the bottom-right corner,

and based on the Route Table,
it will allocate
Internet.

So basically, except for
10.0.0.0/16, you need to go through
NAT Gateway for other addresses.

And the NAT Gateway
will be on the public subnet.

Its outbound connections will go
through the NAT Gateway.

You can see on the left there
are some web servers.

They are the web servers that are
facing the real users.

They have their own
elastic IPs,
namely external IPs.
Other people can access

these external IPs via
the Internet Gateway.

C? Correct. Good.

Lastly I want to talk about
ELB and Route 53.

Allow me to explain.
Actually,

in addition to AZ that
can be used as a backup,
if you want to create a web server
or any services in a VPC,
we would also suggest that
our client can use
Elastic Load Balancing, which can
be the only port to the outside.

When traffic comes in,
it can be distributed to
several machines on the back end.
For the management of machines,

you can also use
Auto Scaling Group.
Auto Scaling Group means that
it can automatically scale up and
down the machines based on workload
to increase or decrease capacity.
Why increase or decrease capacity?

Let’s use a general
service for example,
the time for its peak and
lowest traffic every day is
actually almost the same.

For example,
if it’s a game service,
its peak traffic hours are usually
after 6pm every day, and then
decrease after 12am.

So during these hours,
you can do a predictive scale,
and after midnight, you can
scale down the instance.

You don’t need to
waste the idle instances, and
reduce your costs.
I want to talk about another
interview tip here.
Take load balancing for example.

For load balancing,
if you scan the QR Code

on the top-right corner,
you’ll see that

there are currently four
types of load balancing.

The QR Code will
take you to a table,
which will explain each type
of load balancing in details.
For example,
We have network load balancing,
application load balancing,
and gateway load balancing, etc.

It explains each type of
load balancing,
their individual functions, and
their characteristics.
I actually suggest that when
you are preparing for an interview,
and you actually

don’t know what to
prepare for the protocols,
such as what
we just mentioned earlier,

we actually listed something
like TCP or HTTP,
but you think they are too broad,
you want something more in-depth,
you want a specific direction,
I’d suggest that you take a look.
Let’s take ELB for example.
In the table I just mentioned,

you can see that,
for example,
ALB supports SNI,
or supports WebSocket,
or supports HTTP2.

NLB might
support ALPN in TLS.

You can expect this to be the
interview question that we may ask.
Because when we are solving,

for example, ELB issues
for the clients,

you are expected to know
the relevant knowledge.

Like you need to know what SNI is,
and how does it work?

You need to know how
WebSocket works, as well as the
common issues for troubleshooting.
You need to know that, if you
are interviewing for network ELB,
the most common failure may be
HTTP 500 or 400 errors.
What are the possible reasons for
each 500 or 400 error code?

I actually suggest that
you need to prepare
for the interview based on the
service you are applying for, and
take a look at its official page,
to find out about the protocols
that it uses, and the functions or
more in-depth technical skills.
And then you can figure out

whether you need to improve
yourself in these skills.

Ok, lastly,
as for Route 53,

Route 53 is a
DNS web service
hosted by AWS.
It offers Domain Name Registration,
as well as DNS routing.
It’s also used for health checks.
Two common routing examples:
The first one is called
failover.

For example,
you have two resources:
primary and backup ones, and you
maintain health checks on them.
When there is failure in resource A,
or failure in the primary resource,

Route 53 will automatically
switch to resource B,
namely the backup resource, and
switch back upon health recovery.

This is one type.
And another type of routing
is based on geolocation.
We can automatically detect
the geolocation of the clients, and
provide them with your setting.

For example,
for users from Taiwan accessing
an EC2 in Singapore or Tokyo, you
show the Traditional Chinese page.
For users from Europe or the US,
you provide the English page.
This is the function.
Ok.
So this is my
brief introduction.

I hope everyone can
have some basic
understanding about the VPC.
